Headline to the intro

Subhead to the intro

The Alberta Tar sands hold 170 billion barrels of recoverable oil, one of the largest reserves in the world.
Thanks to technological advances, that ultra thick oil, called bitumen, is easier — and potentially much more profitable — to recover than in the past.
Production is expected to nearly double within the next decade to as much as 4 million barrels per day.
That puts the region at the center of a massive North American oil economy. The problem is getting bitumen safely to oil refineries across the continent.
As new pipelines have been proposed, opponents have fought back citing concerns about global warming, spills and safety.
Keystone XL, 800,000 barrels a day:
Blocked
Dakota Access, 500,000 barrels:
Protests
Northern Gateway Pipeline, 500,000 barrels:
Rejected
Transmountain Pipeline, 600,000 barrels:
Protests, decision pending
Energy East Pipeline, 1 million barrels:
Protests
All that opposition has forced the oil to flow down the path of least resistance:
An old pipeline route that has been in existence for more than 60 years.
Capacity has been increased by adding lines.
Increasing the flow.
And sidestepping regulations.
So much oil can be routed through Wisconsin that can top the oil brought in from Saudi Arabia, Venezuela and Mexico — combined.
And the company that owns the pipeline is considering adding a fourth line — one that would dwarf the rejected Keystone XL.
But Wisconsin is not the destination. In the oil economy, the state is mostly just the highway.
The pipelines cross rivers and wetlands … go through cities and towns
And the pathways are prone to accidents.
In Michigan, one pipeline carries oil under the Great Lakes. Critics say those 50-year-old pipes carry the risk of a catastrophic spill.
Activists in Michigan are demanding that pipeline be shut down
If it is, there is one logical spot for even more oil to flow.
